text: cyclist came off their bike in the underground car park. migrated from legacy cairs incident #34428at approx. 7:40am on friday 18th august a cyclist came off their bike in the underground car park. first aiders were called, and after initial care an ambulance was called as the individual was unable to get up and was suffering from pain and nausea. paramedics were able to bring the ip to their feet, they then provided paracetamol and ibuprofen and recommended rest. initial feedback is that the wet weather conditions and slippery surface in the car park caused the cyclist to slip and come off their bike. further information to follow. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

breeding birds nest ground stripping was undertaken at d83 prior to a breeding bird survey by an ecologist / ornithologist. an ecologist arrived on site at around 0800 (08/06/2017) however mobilization and stripping had commenced the previous day (07/06/2017). works have been stopped at this location until further notice as a burst utility pipe needs to be diverted around the pad. breeding bird surveys will be undertaken on the route of the scottish water water pipe diversion, and around the tower pad prior to further works commencing.

ip felt a metal particle enter their eye while they were carrying out grinding work on a grating panel they were fabricating migrated from legacy cairs incident #40175ip was fabricating new grating panels in the fab shop on the north cormorantwhilst grinding, the ip nudged their rpe which in turn slightly moved their goggles and allowed a particle to reach their eyeip stopped work immediately and visited the medicthe medic successfully removed the particle and the ip returned to work with no restrictions or further issuesdue to migration issues (inability to create actions in cairs), the following actions have created;1) supervisor to ensure ip triesadifferent combination of goggles and masks available to find a fit that will not move the goggles while working. ensure that the ip is face fitted for the type of mask if required. complete; work party instructed to wear an air fed mask during this activity 2) carry out worksite visits where goggles and masks are used in conjunction with a task over a 3 week period to ensure personnel rpe and goggles fit. complete; work site monitoring completed and no issues identified migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

welder was observed performing butt weld on top of a make shift platform ie wooden pallets stored three high. potential for incident was both fire with combustible material being in a hot work area and employee was also working at height. migrated from legacy cairs incident #31424employee was observed tig welding a spool on top of wooden pallets stored three high at approximately 1100am on monday 26/09/2016 within bay 3 of the fabrication services workshop. this unsafe act was not only a potential hazard due to combustible material being in a hot work area but also posed a working at height risk as no edge protection was in place around the makeshift platform.on questioning both the supervisor and welder in question it was evident that there was a lack of hazard awareness on both parties which led to the unsafe act taken place. the job was stopped and the makeshift platform dismantled and aluminium hop ups were used to complete the remainder of the welding migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

electrical engineer installing pv panels, vomitting and headache electrical engineer(ee)  was installing pv panels needed to get out of sun as per heat illness prevention plan. given cool place to relax, rehydrate with water ("sqwincher" popsicle) and recovered.  taken to cooling trailer to re-hydrated, electrolytes, orange and kept in air conditioned trailer.

ip reports was out on helideck yesterday with helideck crew loading baggage on helicopter and was walking across helideck with baggage and felt a pop and burn feeling to left knee. migrated from legacy cairs incident #30113ip reports was out on helideck yesterday with helideck crew loading baggage on helicopter and was walking across helideck with baggage and felt a pop and burn feeling to left knee. ip did not feel any further pain and continued work. ip began feeling increasing discomfort to left knee throughout day and today pain worse. ip reports to health center this afternoon for assessment of left knee pain. treatment provided. rtw full duties. rtc in am and as needed any further issues or concerns. supervisor notified. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

an electrician got short-term (0.5 sec) power through hand - hand, between phase and ground (130v ac) an electrician got short-term power throughput (<0.5 sec) from hand to hand, between phase and ground (130v ac) during work on the pdss project.the incident occurred in connection with work in a tight distribution cabinet containing a plc, terminal blocks and a circuit breaker. when the fitter had to push the terminal blocks and automatic circuit breaker onto din rail to accommodate new equipment, the circuit breaker was touched on the underside with a hand, while the other hand held onto a din rail of aluminum. (the circuit breaker has two small uninsulated 18 x 6 mm sections on the underside). the work team consisted of two electricians (hired personnel).  the incident notified to the wood installation manager. medic. sought for check. no abnormalities were found. back to work immediately after.conducted conversation with involved personnel where the importance of compliance with fse requirements and understanding of risk was reviewed.completed "time-out" with the entire work team where learning from the incident and focus on safety for further work were reviewed.reported to subcontracting company for follow-up of own personnel.reported to dsb and nav.prepared safety alert / lessons learned (one pager)

truck e-1298 was hit on driver rear end quarter panel by pepsi semi truck. migrated from legacy cairs incident #28559employee was parked at loewen farm and lumber when a pepsi semi truck was leaving the loading and unloading dock and as he was exiting the business, he made a sharp turn right into highway 62/385 before clearing path resulting in hitting truck e-1298 in driver side rear quarter panel. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

an unauthorized visitor entry was reported at the west side of the horseshoe building during lunch time yesterday, the wood campus security team was notified immediately. luckily nobody was hurt and nothing was damaged. migrated from legacy cairs incident #36013an unknown woman approached up behind an employee at her desk. the woman made her somewhat uncomfortable as she wasobviouslylooking at what was on her desk and computerscreen so the employeeminimized the information and asked if shecould help.the woman stated she used to sit there and was looking for another employee. theemployee looked up the person she was wanting to see and that personcurrently resides in another building, so theemployeeoffered to call the person and asked if she checked in with reception. the woman said it wasn't necessaryandstated she "let herself in". the employee went ahead and called the person she was looking for and let him knowthe womanwas looking for him but the guy seemed uncertain as he did not recognize the name. the woman then gave a different last name and then he knew who he was but stilled seemed uncertain. the employee askedhim if she could give her his work number and he agreed. the employee told the woman she would escort her out but the woman immediatelyturned and walked off beforethe employee could hang up the phone and escort her. the employee followed behind her to be sure she left and reported the incident as the woman made her uncomfortable and did notenter the building throughreception, but probably followed another employee into the building. she later learned that the employee had worked with the company about 4 years ago. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

oil tanker in the process of positioning to the calm buoy had lost all propulsion and was drifting toward the fpso. esd for complete field shut-in was activated. abandon ship alarm and muster activated. migrated from legacy cairs incident #39627in preparation for a normal product offloading receiving oil tanker in the process of positioning to the calm buoy lost all propulsion and was drifting toward the fpso tankerlocation was approximately 200 mts off the fpso starboard sideesd for complete field shut-inwas activatedabandon ship alarmactivated and muster was underwaybefore abandon ship and life boat launching commenced the tanker drift was brought under control andtanker was repositioned using additional support fromvessel pacific retriever that was in the areaabandon ship alarm cleared commencement to bring the assets back online was activated tanker wasnow positionedapproximately 500mts clear and downwind of the fpso, still without propulsion but under the control of the two support vessels tanker was empty and in the process of positioning to connect to the calm buoy when propulsion was lostall alarms cleared and the process of bringing the field back online was underway no lifeboats were launched, or any personnel had evacuated the asset** update ** draft investigation report sent out for review to relevant personnel for comment. final report to be issued after comments are collected. information provided by gp hse manager kt. td 26/09/18. **update** 6/10/18 - delay in final report being issued from kt regarding incident. close out date extended to allow for time until report issued. **update** 8/11/18 - draft report attached to cairs case. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

during tear down of concrete forms an employee felt foreign particles in his eyes. migrated from legacy cairs incident #30870on monday, july 18, 2016 at 8:15 am at the b 800 block of olin blue cube a brazos m&e employee was tearing down concrete forms and felt foreign particles in his eyes. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

covid-19 test, positive wood employee undergoes covid-19 test, has symptoms of tiredness, muscle pain and throat, wood employee was working at home, receives covid-19 test results, february 14 with results positive, at this time staff are quarantined at home, staff visited a doctor, and are undergoing treatment. there are no wood personnel in the contact chain. the infected wood staff notifies their discipline leader and hsse leader, according to procedure, the infected staff is treated by a health specialist, he is isolated in quarantine at home, there is no chain of contact, the staff work at home, due pandemic situation.

employee communicated a positive confirmation for covid-19 an employee reported a confirmed positive test for covid-19 to site management. the employee has been in isolation. wood is identifying those who may have worked in proximity.  appropriate notifications have been completed.

category: mechanical or equipment issue, theft, vehicle incident general
text: stolen catalytic converter from rental vehicle returned home from work and parked and locked the vehcile at about 1730 hrs. sometime between 0100 and 0122, neighbors across the street came out from their house to smoke. they heard a grinding noise, and noticed that there was a green early to mid 2000's ford truck reversing up and down the street. thinking that the truck was experiencing some mehcanincal issues, he started to cross the street to offer some assistance. he called out to the truck, and at that point noticed something moving around underneath the rental truck. the green ford honked three times, a man climbed out from under the rental, got into the green truck, and sped off. around 0122 i went out on my balcony for a smoke, and they called up to me and asked if it was my dodge ram parked around the corner, and that someone had likely stolen the catalytic convertor. i came out, did a circle check of the vechile, found that it was still locked and there was no visible exterior damage. police arrived soon after, took my information as well as a statement from the witnesses. offiicer houle left me with his card, as well as an incident number.   reported incident to police, informed supervisor.

burst potable water line knocked out the plc and shut the plant down at cresswell project works were undertaken to relocate plastic piping of a potable water line at cresswell treatment plant. piping was glued and cured for 2hrs and water reinstated into the line at approximately 1pm. at approximately 2pm a leak was observed at one of the joins. water from the leak had landed on a plc cabinet.  the area was cleared, operations isolated the line upstream and stopped the potable water pumps. the plc cabinet was immediately isolated and the plant shut down.  the plc cabinet and internals were dried. pcs engineer arrived on site responding to the level 1 work order that was raised by operations (wo7791084). one analogue i/o card had failed, was replaced and tested. the plant was back online at approximately 4.45pm. the potable water pipework was re-glued with a different glue (tangit all pressure, suitable for pvc/pvc, abs/pvc and abs/abs pressure joins) the following day (wednesday) , allowed to cure for 24hrs and the potable water line was returned to service on thursday.

glass coffee table fell on the middle toe nail office boy was asked to move the center glass coffee table from the new reception area in 2nd floor into approximate 5 meters from the current location. he did not noticed that there is a glass support from the bottom and so when he lifted the said small table the glass support fell down to his middle toe nail resulting to a minor injury. first aid treatment applied.

tm was picking up trash when he felt slight discomfort in his lower left back.			 team member was picking up trash in block 3a. around 9am the tm started to feel slight discomfort in his lower left back. team member did not notify his supervisor until 12 and continued to work.           actual rating b1 was chosen because discomfort is related to muscle fatigue due to repetitive motion.       potential rating b2 was chosen because symptoms of more severe soft tissue injuries may take longer to develop and be detected.			 when the team member notified his supervisor, he was immediately brought to the safety office. team member was offered  bio freeze, ibuprofen, acetaminophen and a heating pad. acetaminophen was rejected and everything else was accepted. team member was instructed to follow up with safety in the morning. team member was released and has returned to work.

potential acm exposure migrated from legacy cairs incident #34527potential acm exposure notification communication delivered to wood group 31/08/2017 at 8 am.area barricaded.eapl to rectify. report made by non wood group personnel. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

preventable, rental vehicle, medium damage, no injury. drilling contractor asked for assistance moving a compressor from 1 drill location to another while the drilling supervisor left site to get another driller employee on site; while moving the compressor, the truck slid on the icy site conditions and the compressor then pushed the truck on the ice and damaged the rear passenger side of the truck (bumper and corner panel - lights and tailgate were not damaged. incident reported and investigation began.

massy wood employee attempted to place a 16ft tubing with a weight of approximately 42lbs on a scaffold rack when he felt a sharp pain and discomfort to his right wrist. migrated from legacy cairs incident #40243on the december 09th, 2018 at around 11 am , massy wood employee was in the process of demobilizing scaffolding materials on the sub cellar deck from a scaffolding which was being dismantled by himself and a team of scaffolders. while he was attempting to place a 16 ft tubing with a weight of approximately 42lbs on a scaffold rack he felt a sharp pain and discomfort to his right wrist ( existing injury "previously dislocated"). the ip immediately reported the discomfort to the field supervisor and then visited the platform medic. the ip right wrist was examined by the platform medic in which he reported that he had previously dislocated his right wrist two years ago, an application of sport balm was applied to area and a wrist strap was placed on the right wrist, he was then discharge by the medic to return to his duties. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

employee punctured and burned by hot tungsten. the employee, along with another welder, were under the 3301 hrsg, welding on two separate pieces of pipe in tight quarters.  as the other welder was finishing his weld, he pulled his tig rig up and to the right, puncturing the right tricep of his coworker approximately 1/4" with the hot tungsten. the employee was escorted to the safety office by his general foreman.  the wound was cleaned and dressed.  ineos construction coordinator, jody dunbar, and ineos safety were notified.  the employee had never had a tetanus shot so he was escorted off site as a precaution.

a wah site employee decided to take a covid test following the reporting of a positive case in the workplace. he received a positive result. a wah employee working at (kfupm, bpcc) site decided to take a covid test following the reporting of a positive case in the workplace. he received a positive result on 10th june. employee asked to self-isolate for 14 days, offices disinfected and contact tracing completed.

team member (tm) sustained a small 3/8 when they slipped on some grading during cleaning operations during clean out operations of the scr (selective catalytic reduction) unit we had a team member(tm) misplace their footing resulting in a first aid injury. tm was vacuuming debris from slots in the unit, tm slipped next to the  10"w 18"d slot in the grading; scraping their shin along the slotting/metal in the unit. axiom involved. basic first aid measures in place. safety stand down held, we discussed hazards we create while executing work, and the steps to prevent workplace hazards.corrective action is to lay down a barrier to protect workers from falling.

the wood employee was under monitoring at the hotel and was tested as positive for covid. the wood employee was under monitoring at the hotel and was tested as positive for covid. he is asymptomatic.  isolation and medical recommendation.

category: covid, general illness or health issue
text: a wood employee has been tested positive to covid-19 a wood employee has been tested positive to covid-19. symptoms started the 24th october (sore throat) and he didn't come to the office. he did the test and the 28th he received the results confirming he was positive. contact tracing started but no close contacts have been identified.

wood worker has had a positive result for covid-19 disease, while under preventative quarantine to embark on whp-a the ip, an irata fitter, was at comfort hotel in macaé, under social isolation inside of the room, as part of a preventative quarantine to embark on whp-a (peregrino field, client: equinor), wood received by e-mail (with no test report or test result attached) the indication he was not approved for embarking, due to a positive result on the "rt-pcr" test (fluid sample extracted on april 28th, information sent by e-mail on april 30th, positive result sent to wood doctor today - may 1st). the ip remains asymptomatic and it is not possible to establish a connection between the disease and any labor activity. the ip was kept into the hotel and will be sent to rio in a car (he and the driver will have masks and available alcohol in gel, with opened car windows). the reason for the transferring is coming from lessons learned from previous cases: 1) there was an indication of brazilian health authority to not bring a positive case to the house and family and 2) in other case, where the ip was initially asymptomatic (offshore) and started feeling the effects later on, going to the hospital twice, having his health condition worsened very fast and being admitted in the hospital quickly due to the proximity of the hotel.

the wood employee was tested offshore and show positive result for covid. the wood employee was tested offshore and show positive result for covid. he is asymptomatic. isolation and medical recommendation.

an employee received first aid after exposure to hydrated lime. at approximately 1:00 pm on friday, february 25, a vac truck crew was purging hydrated lime powder from the 4-inch line that is used to fill lime silo a.  i/e was holding the 4-inch corrugated vac tube against the open end of the line when the vac tube lurched, creating a gap. a plume of lime powder blew out of the line and contacted i/e's face and neck.  a severity of b1 was selected as there was one individual requiring first aid. a potential severity of c2 was selected due to the potential for hydrated lime exposure to require further medical treatment, and the potential for a second employee who was operating the vac truck controls about 6 feet away to have been exposed. work stopped. i/e immediately went to nearby admin building to rinse eyes and face, accompanied by supervisor.  client supervision and ert notified.  i/e evaluated by ert who recommended a full shower in onsite facility.  i/e has returned to work and is doing well.

category: fall from or working at height issue
text: wood employee was observed standing on the 6th rung of 10' portable step ladder without fall protection while performing a work task. a wood employee and co-woker were tasked to install some piping and valves. employee a  was using a 10' portable step ladder while doing task. employee a stepped up onto the 6th rung of the ladder (above 4' tie off level) in order to reach the valve to install the bolts and was observed by a client hsse representative as not being tied off.  employee b (co-worker) was working with employee a and did not make an intervention of employee a. client hsse representative stopped the job and contacted wood supervision and safety. job was stopped and a immediate investigation started. both wood employees were removed from site pending outcome of investigation.

struck by falling part of powered vehicle still attached an employee was preparing a finished boat for shipment. he was placing a battery in the motor box when the lid of the box inadvertently closed and crushed his right big toe, amputating part of the bone.

caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, unspecified an employee was conducting maintenance work on an overhead garage door when the employee's thumb was caught in the overhead door's chain drive, resulting in a partial left thumb amputation.

caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, unspecified on february 23, 2021, an employee was removing 4-inch by 4-inch posts from the tops of stacks of veneer before they were loaded into an industrial veneer dryer. while the employee was between stacks of pine veneer on the dryer's infeed chains, the employee was caught between two of the racks and suffered pelvis fractures. she was hospitalized.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment on april 26, 2016, at approximately 4:00 p.m., an employee was adjusting the brush table, which is part of the equipment that loads buns into bags. to adjust the brush table, the employee loosens a lock bolt, slides the brush table forward or backward, and retightens the lock bolt. while adjusting the brush table with his right hand, the employee's right index finger was pinched between the pusher on the bagger and the brush table, amputating the fingertip.

injured by physical contact with person while restraining, subduing-unintentional on october 20, 2020, at approximately 11:45 pm, an employee was kicked in the chest while trying to restrain a combative patient. the employee developed dizziness, chest pain, and shortness of breath and was hospitalized.

category: lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury
text: struck by swinging or slipping object, other than handheld, n.e.c. a temporary employee utilized an overhead crane to move a concrete panel from one area to another. the panel started moving towards a post. the employee put his hand on the concrete panel to stop it before hitting the post, but his left hand was caught between the panel and the post.  the employee sustained a crushing injury to the left hand and was hospitalized for surgery.

injured by slipping or swinging object held by injured worker an employee was using a reciprocating saw and holding the handle/trigger with his right hand. when the reciprocating saw started, it pulled his glove and left fifth finger into the quick lock blade clamp, lacerating and fracturing it. his finger was partially amputated.

category: hand or arm injury, knife incident
text: injured by slipping or swinging object held by injured worker an employee was removing blades from a cane knife when the blades amputated the employee's left middle finger.
ignition of vapors, gases, or liquids an employee was relighting a residential pilot light when a fire/explosion occurred. the employee was hospitalized with second degree burns to the face and arms.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was slicing a tomato near a 90-degree belt on a conveyor line when her hand got caught underneath the belt. her left pinky finger was amputated below the nailbed.

caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, unspecified an employee was trying to remove a chain that was bound up in a door stacker machine. when the employee removed the chain, it became free and rolled over. the employee's fingers were then caught between the chain and gear, resulting in possible middle and ring fingertip amputations on the right hand.

category: fall from or working at height issue, head or face injury
text: fall through surface or existing opening 6 to 10 feet an employee was inspecting an attic when he fell approximately 9 to 10 feet through the ceiling and struck his head on the concrete garage floor. he suffered a head laceration and multiple fractures.

category: fall from or working at height issue, head or face injury, slips & trips
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was on a scaffold preparing an area for masonry work when the employee fell from the scaffold and onto some bricks, suffering a back injury and head laceration.

caught in running equipment or machinery, n.e.c. an employee was manufacturing copper pipe fittings using a hydraulic press when a fitting fell into the machine. the employee was attempting to retrieve the fitting when the die came down on the employee's left index finger, amputating it at the first knuckle.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee was changing the drive belts on a fan unit. his left ring finger got caught between one of the drive belts and the motor pulley/sheath as the belt turned on the pulley. his left ring finger was amputated below the first joint and he required surgery.

part of occupantís body caught between vehicle and other object in nonroadway transport incident an employee was operating a zero-turn lawn mower when he approached a steel cable approximately 3 feet off the ground. he became caught in the cable, and both of his legs were lacerated and crushed between the cable and the mower's mowing deck.
